Two points:
1. Putting a physical limitation on our ANNs just like the human brain might
actually help us in limiting the search space for coming up with a good
solution, quicker.  
2. I'd read some papers on Gas Nets (the work being done at Sussex). They
used some physical 2D placement of neurons to determine the amount of Gas
being spread across the network. Has anyone from the Gas Net community tried
to use the same 2D configuration to affect the ANN connectivity/growth?

Regards,
Umer Iqbal

-----Original Message-----
From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Monday, August 08, 2005 1:53 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Linked

Philip Tucker wrote:

> [...]
>
> 2) I'm sure real neural networks have clusters.  It's debatable 
> whether this is a necessary feature or simply a byproduct of biology - 
> it's much easier for two neurons in close spatial proximity to be 
> connected than those farther apart.  But do neural networks have hubs?

Not sure but I thought I'd add that the clusters in mammalian brains are 
arranged in columns. The neural column is, I think, the basic unit of 
repetition, and interconnections within a column have been observed to 
be far more numerous than those between columns.


> 4) The NEAT paradigm is not biased toward either of these network 
> features.  Any node has an equal chance connecting to any other node 
> (excepting the initial connections between input and output nodes).

Which would be more like the case /within/ a neural column, for example, 
which contains far more neurons (approx. 100k is a figure I recall) than 
any NEAT evolved ANN I've ever seen. If clustering is a strategy for 
dealing with complexity, and our ANN's don't get very complex then it's 
not clear that it would be a useful strategy to engineer into NEAT. On 
the other hand clustering may happen at numerous levels, so e.g.a neural 
column may contain sub-clusters, some of which may contain very small 
groups similar in size to our ANN's.


> Despite this lack of bias in the evolutionary model, do clusters or 
> hubs emerge?  If they are crucial features of an effective network, 
> should we build such biases into the evolutionary process?  For 
> example, the likelihood of a connection being added between two nodes 
> could be proportional to the connectivity distance between the two 
> (this could be based on a unidirectional or bidirectional traversal of 
> connections).  Or, the weight could be proportional to this distance.  
> As an alternative to connectivity distance, we could give the nodes a 
> spatial layout, perhaps on a 2-dimensional surface, and have 
> connection mutation be relative to that spatial distance.

As an aside, laying neuron's out in a grid space, 2D, 3D or otherwise 
(why not 4D or more?) is something I've considered when thinking about 
indirect encodings. 'growing' neurons within a limited space is one way 
of preventing an indirect encoding from growing ANN's too large to 
simulate.

Actually when I started out doing work on neuro-evolution my first 
instinct was to use grid layouts (I used hexagonal grids) and the 
question of how many dimensions I should use came up. It occured to me 
that real world neural nets exist in 3D due to physical constriants - 
there are only 3 spacial dimensions! - and this presents a limit to the 
amount of connectivity a biological neural net can achieve, because of 
the physical size of neurons and their connections and the limited space 
available. Therefore it makes sense to connect more to your neighbours 
than to distant neurons.

Of course the ANN's in NEAT are effectively dimensionless, any neuron 
can connect to any other without any limits or concept of relative 
distance and the lack of this restriction is one of the benefits we have 
over biology. Perhaps though clustering is not just a strategy for 
dealing with physical limitations, but actually has other positive side 
effects.

Trying to engineer some kind of clustering factor into NEAT is an 
interesting idea. I don;t think it's a substitute for the  existing 
modular NEAT approaches because there is no repetition of 
clusters(unless maybe you can identify them), but it may be a more 
efficient way of evolving small ANN's in general.

Colin
